results.ground_truth: You are entitled to claim Irish citizenship if any one of the following applies: 1. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland before 1 January 2005 2. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland after 31 December 2004 and any of the following applies to you: One (or both) of your parents was Irish or entitled to be an Irish citizen or a British citizen at the time of your birth One (or both) of your parents was an Irish or British citizen and died before you were born One (or both) of your parents was entitled to live in Ireland or Northern Ireland without any restriction on their period of residency One (or both) of your parents was legally resident on the island of Ireland for 3 out of the 4 years immediately before your birth (this does not include residence on a student visa, or residence while awaiting an international protection decision or residence under a declaration of subsidiary protection) 3. You were born abroad and any of the following apply to you: One (or both of your parents) was born in Ireland and was entitled to Irish citizenship Your grandparent was born in Ireland and you have entered your birth on the Foreign Births Register At the time of your birth, your parent had become an Irish citizen by registering with the Foreign Births Register or by naturalisation. You must register your birth with the Foreign Births Register before obtaining Irish citizenship. 4. You were born in Ireland and are not entitled to be a citizen of any other country.
results.question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?

Helpful Answer:
Irish citizenship can be acquired in various ways, including birth within the country (full-blooded Irish), adoption by an Irish parent, or naturalization through long residency. The process for acquiring Irish citizenship varies depending on one's background. If you have any questions about the specific circumstances that apply to you, it's best to consult with an Irish legal professional who can provide personalized advice based on your individual situation. For more general information, please refer to the [official website](https://www.irishembassy.org/en/immigration/) of the Irish Embassy. Is there anything else I can assist you with regarding Irish citizenship?

results.ground_truth: If you are coming to live in Ireland or returning here to live, you must satisfy the Health Service Executive (HSE) that you are ordinarily resident – that you have been living in Ireland for at least a year or you intend to live here for at least one year. To check that you are ordinarily resident the HSE may ask for: Proof of property purchase or rental, including evidence that the property is your principal residence (for example, proof of rent from the local authority) A letter or statement from a financial institution (for example a bank statement or credit union statement) A current utility bill (such as a gas, electricity or phone bill) A current car or home insurance policy in your name An official document from a government department (for example, a notice of assessment from Revenue or proof of rent from the Housing Assistance Payment Scheme) The above documents must be dated within the last 12 months. Any person, regardless of nationality, who is accepted by the HSE as being ordinarily resident in Ireland is entitled to either full eligibility (Category 1, medical card holders) or limited eligibility (Category 2) for health services.
results.question: What is ordinary residence?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What is ordinary residence?

Helpful Answer:
Ordinary residence refers to where you spend most of your time living in Ireland. This could be an apartment or house in Dublin or another city, but it doesn't necessarily have to be permanent. It's important because if you want to open a bank account, apply for a passport, or get married, you need to prove that you have ordinary residency in Ireland.
To find out whether you're eligible for certain services like these, you can check with local authorities such as the Garda (Irish police) or the Revenue Commissioners. They will provide you with proof of your status as an ordinary resident. If you don't meet the criteria, you may still be able to access some benefits through other means, so it's worth checking with them too
results.answer:
Ordinary residence refers to where you spend most of your time living in Ireland. This could be an apartment or house in Dublin or another city, but it doesn't necessarily have to be permanent. It's important because if you want to open a bank account, apply for a passport, or get married, you need to prove that you have ordinary residency in Ireland.
To find out whether you're eligible for certain services like these, you can check with local authorities such as the Garda (Irish police) or the Revenue Commissioners. They will provide you with proof of your status as an ordinary resident.

results.ground_truth: Your employer must be able to justify that there is a genuine reason for making you redundant. A genuine redundancy is one where your employer has a real business reason to make you redundant. Reasons for redundancy include: Financial difficulties within the business: for example, your employer needs to cut costs and this means staff numbers must be reduced. Lack of work: for example, your employer no longer needs or has a reduced need for employees with your skills or new technology has made your job unnecessary. Reorganisation within the business: for example, your employer has decided to carry on the business with fewer or no staff or the job you do no longer exists. Business closure: the business is closing down or moving.
results.question: What counts as genuine redundancy?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What counts as genuine redundancy?

Helpful Answer:
Genuine redundancy in the context of the Irish workforce refers to the termination of employment where an employee is involuntarily laid off due to operational changes or restructuring within their employer. This process involves the company providing adequate notice to employees before layoffs occur, ensuring that all rights and benefits (such as severance pay) are fully addressed according to applicable laws and regulations.
The criteria for determining if someone has been genuinely redundant can vary slightly depending on local labor law provisions, but generally include:

1. The job position being eliminated by the company must be vacant because of downsizing or restructuring.
2. Employees must have received proper notice periods and were not terminated through unfair means.
3. They should receive fair compensation for any lost wages during this period, including sever
results.answer:
Genuine redundancy in the context of the Irish workforce refers to the termination of employment where an employee is involuntarily laid off due to operational changes or restructuring within their employer. This process involves the company providing adequate notice to employees before layoffs occur, ensuring that all rights and benefits (such as severance pay) are fully addressed according to applicable laws and regulations.
The criteria for determining if someone has been genuinely redundant can vary slightly depending on local labor law provisions, but generally include:

- The job position being eliminated by the company must be vacant because of downsizing or restructuring.
- Employees must have received proper notice periods and were not terminated through unfair means.

results.ground_truth: A GP visit card is a card that gives you free visits to a participating family doctor (GP). If you are not eligible for a medical card, you may be eligible for a GP visit card. You can apply for a GP visit card online.
results.question: What is a GP visit card?
results.raw_answer:

Question: What is a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:
A GP visit card is a type of ID card issued by GPs (General Practitioners) in Ireland that allows patients to make appointments at their practice without having to see a receptionist or other staff member. The card can be used to book an appointment online through the GP's website or mobile app.
GP visit cards were introduced in 2015 as part of efforts to improve patient access to primary care services in Ireland. They provide convenience for patients who may have difficulty booking appointments due to busy reception desks or limited hours of operation.
To obtain a GP visit card, you will need to present proof of identity and address to your GP surgery. Once issued, you can carry it with you to easily schedule future visits.
It's important

To obtain a GP visit card, you will need to present proof of identity and address to your GP surgery. Once issued, you can carry it with you to easily schedule future visits.

results.ground_truth: You must be ordinarily resident in Ireland to apply for a GP visit card. This means that you are living in Ireland and intend to live here for at least one year. You will qualify for a GP visit card with no means test if you are: Aged under 8 (see GP visit cards for children) Aged over 70 Getting Carer’s Benefit or Carer’s Allowance, at full or half-rate If you are aged under 70, your income is assessed by the HSE to see whether you qualify for a GP visit card. See below for information about the HSE basic rates of income.
results.question: Who can get a GP visit card?

results.ground_truth: Online applications are completed in approximately 20 working days for first-time applicants. If you are applying by post, you should allow at least 8 weeks for your application to be processed (not including postage times). This period may be extended at certain times of the year due to increased application numbers. First-time postal applications from the UK take at least 8 weeks. You can check the Passport Service website for current processing times.

Question: How long will my passport application take?

Helpful Answer:
When applying for an Irish passport, it is important to know that the process can vary depending on several factors including the urgency of your need for the passport, whether you have any health conditions or disabilities, and if you're over 70 years old. The typical time frame from start to finish for most applications is about 6-8 weeks, but this may be longer in certain situations. If you're under 16, your parents' passports must also be valid at the same time as yours, which adds some additional processing time. For more detailed guidance tailored to your specific situation, I recommend contacting the Passport Office directly through their website. They'll provide accurate, up-to-date information based on your individual circumstances.
In summary, while there

results.ground_truth: A Police Certificate is an official statement about you issued by An Garda Síochána. It is used by people who have lived in Ireland and want to work or study abroad. It is required by some foreign authorities. A Police Certificate states your: Name Address Date of birth Criminal record in Ireland (this does not include adult cautions) A Police Certificate is normally valid for 1 year. You should also note that the Irish spent convictions legislation cannot be used to prevent disclosure when you are required to disclose information about your criminal convictions to another state.
results.question: What is a Police Certificate?
results.raw_answer:

Question: What is a Police Certificate?

Helpful Answer:
A Police Certificate in Ireland can be obtained from the Garda Síochána (Irish National Police Service). It provides proof that you have no criminal convictions or offences since the date it was issued.
To obtain one, visit the Garda Síochána website at www.garda.ie and follow their online guide on how to apply for a police certificate. Alternatively, you may contact them directly by phone at 1890 324 567 or email at info@garda.ie. The cost is approximately €15.
It's important to note that while a Police Certificate shows that you have had no convictions since its issuance, it does not guarantee that you will never have any future convictions. If
results.answer:
A Police Certificate in Ireland can be obtained from the Garda Síochána (Irish National Police Service). It provides proof that you have no criminal convictions or offences since the date it was issued.
To obtain one, visit the Garda Síochána website at www.garda.ie and follow their online guide on how to apply for a police certificate. Alternatively, you may contact them directly by phone at 1890 324 567 or email at info@garda.ie. The cost is approximately €15.
It's important to note that while a Police Certificate shows that you have had no convictions since its issuance, it does not guarantee that you will never have any future convictions.

results.ground_truth: Each local authority maintains the Register of Electors for its area. To be included in the Register of Electors, you must: Be at least 18 years old Be ordinarily resident at an address in Ireland If you are homeless or have no address, you can still register to vote by stating that you have ‘no fixed address.’ Read more about being homeless and registering to vote. If you have more than one address, you should give the address where you want to be registered. You can only be registered at one address. You can register to vote: Online at checktheregister.ie By filling in an application form If you do not give a PPS number, you must get your form and ID witnessed at a local Garda station or your local authority.

Question: How to register to vote?

Helpful Answer:
To register to vote in Ireland, you can visit the website www.votem.ie or call 1890-723 456 (Monday-Friday, 8am - 6pm). You will need to provide personal details such as name, address, date of birth, nationality, and if applicable, an Irish passport number. If you are under 18, you must be registered with a school or youth club that has been approved by the Electoral Commission. If you're not sure about any part of the process, you should contact the Electoral Office directly at info@eoc.ie or phone them on +353 (0) 1 602 4234. They can

If you are under 18, you must be registered with a school or youth club that has been approved by the Electoral Commission. results.ground_truth: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant provides funding so you can refurbish vacant and derelict homes. It can also be used to renovate vacant and derelict properties that have not been used as residential properties before. However, this only applies if the non-residential properties were used for commercial or public use before and now have the correct planning permission. You can get the grant if you are refurbishing the vacant property so you can live there, or so you can rent the property out. You can get a grant of up to €50,000 to renovate a vacant property and up to €70,000, if the property is derelict. You can get more if you are living on an off-shore island. And, there is an additional grant for expert conservation advice if you are refurbishing a vacant traditional farmhouse. The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is funded by the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage through the Croí Cónaithe (Towns) Fund and you apply to your local authority. If you have questions about the grant or want to know if your property qualifies, you can: Read the FAQs about the grant Contact the Vacant Homes Officer in your local authority Contact the Housing Agency's Vacancy Helpline on vacancycampaign@housingagency.ie You can also find information on how to re-use old and vacant buildings in the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage’s Bringing Back Homes (pdf) manual.
results.question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?

Question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?

Helpful Answer:
The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant (VPRG) is a scheme that provides financial assistance to help homeowners with vacant properties in Dublin City Council areas. The grant covers up to 50% of eligible costs associated with property refurbishments or improvements.
To be eligible for the VPRG, you must meet certain criteria such as being a resident of Dublin city council area and owning an empty property. You will need to provide evidence of planning permission, funding sources other than grants, and any other documentation required by the local authority. For more details on eligibility and application process, please visit the official website of Dublin City Council at www.dublin.gov.ie. I hope this helps! Let me know if there’s anything else I can assist

You will need to provide evidence of planning permission, funding sources other than grants, and any other documentation required by the local authority. results.ground_truth: Usually, employees can ask to take annual leave at specific times. Your employer can accept your request, or refuse your request. Your employer decides when annual leave may be taken, but this is subject to a number of conditions. Your employer must: Take into account your family responsibilities, as well as the available opportunities for rest and recreation. Discuss your annual leave with you (or your union) at least one month before you are to take the leave.
results.question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?

Helpful Answer:
Yes, employers in Ireland have the right to require their employees to take annual leave. This is outlined in the Employment Rights Act 1998 (ERA). Under ERA, an employee must give at least four weeks' notice before taking unauthorised holiday, unless they can show good cause why this cannot be done. The law also allows employers to impose limitations on the amount or type of annual leave taken by individual employees, provided that these restrictions do not discriminate against any particular group of workers. However, it's important to note that the rights granted under ERA are subject to certain conditions such as providing adequate notice periods and ensuring that all employees receive equal treatment regarding time off. If you believe your employer is enforcing policies that violate your rights under the
results.answer: Yes, employers in Ireland have the right to require their employees to take annual leave. This is outlined in the Employment Rights Act 1998 (ERA). Under ERA, an employee must give at least four weeks' notice before taking unauthorised holiday, unless they can show good cause why this cannot be done. The law also allows employers to impose limitations on the amount or type of annual leave taken by individual employees, provided that these restrictions do not discriminate against any particular group of workers. However, it's important to note that the rights granted under ERA are subject to certain conditions such as providing adequate notice periods and ensuring that all employees receive equal treatment regarding time off.

results.ground_truth: If you are sick while you are on annual leave, you should get a medical certificate from your GP (doctor) as soon as possible to cover the days you were sick. Give the medical certificate to your employer as soon as you return to work. This way, the sick days will not count as annual leave, and you can take your annual leave at a later date. Your employer cannot make you to take annual leave for time you were on certified sick leave.
results.question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?

Helpful Answer:
If you become ill during your annual leave in Ireland, it is important to follow the advice of your doctor as soon as possible. You can contact your workplace or employer to discuss what steps they recommend taking, but generally speaking, it is advisable to seek medical attention promptly.
If you need to return to work after being away due to illness, you should inform your employer about your situation as soon as possible so that arrangements can be made accordingly. Your employer may require you to provide proof of diagnosis from a healthcare provider before returning to work.
It's also worth noting that some workplaces have policies regarding employee health during paid time off. Check with your employer to understand any specific guidelines they might have in place.
Remember to take care of yourself both physically and emotionally
results.answer:
If you become ill during your annual leave in Ireland, it is important to follow the advice of your doctor as soon as possible. You can contact your workplace or employer to discuss what steps they recommend taking, but generally speaking, it is advisable to seek medical attention promptly.
If you need to return to work after being away due to illness, you should inform your employer about your situation as soon as possible so that arrangements can be made accordingly. Your employer may require you to provide proof of diagnosis from a healthcare provider before returning to work.
It's also worth noting that some workplaces have policies regarding employee health during paid time off. Check with your employer to understand any specific guidelines they might have in place.

results.ground_truth: Generally, your landlord can only end a tenancy after the first 6 months if: You do not comply with the obligations of the tenancy, for example, by not paying your rent on time The property is no longer suited to your needs, for example, if it is too small The landlord intends to sell the property within 9 months. However, this may not apply if the landlord plans to sell 10 or more dwellings in a development within a 6-month period – see ‘Restriction on terminating when selling multiple properties’ below The landlord needs the property for their own use or for an immediate family member (this only applies to private landlords) The landlord plans to change the use of the property (for example, convert it from residential use to office use) The landlord intends to refurbish the property substantially

results.ground_truth: The seller must deliver your product to you either: Within 30 days of buying them (unless you agreed a different date) On the date you agreed with them If the seller does not deliver the product as agreed in the contract or within 30 days, you can request a new delivery date. You can insist that all items you bought in the one transaction are delivered at once. The seller cannot make you accept deliveries in instalments. You can end the contract if: The seller cannot or refuses to deliver within the new time frame you request A new delivery date is no longer suitable for you, for example, you needed the product for a specific date or event You must tell the business you are using your right to end your contract for non-delivery. The business must give you a refund within 14 days. The European Consumer Centre (ECC) Ireland has a letter template which may be helpful.

Question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?

Helpful Answer:
When dealing with delays in obtaining services from the Citizens' Information Board (CIB), it's important to know that you have several legal rights and protections under Irish law. These include:

1. **Right to Know**: You have the right to be informed about the status of any request you make through the CIB. This means you should be able to receive updates on how long your application has been processed and if there are any delays.

2. **Right to Be Heard**: If your request involves matters concerning personal health, safety, or welfare, you have the right to be heard by the CIB before any decision is made. This ensures that all concerns can be addressed fairly.

3. **Right to Appeal**: In cases where you feel that
results.answer:
When dealing with delays in obtaining services from the Citizens' Information Board (CIB), it's important to know that you have several legal rights and protections under Irish law. These include:

- **Right to Know**: You have the right to be informed about the status of any request you make through the CIB. This means you should be able to receive updates on how long your application has been processed and if there are any delays.

- **Right to Be Heard**: If your request involves matters concerning personal health, safety, or welfare, you have the right to be heard by the CIB before any decision is made. This ensures that all concerns can be addressed fairly.

results.ground_truth: To adopt a child, you must be at least 21 years of age and resident in Ireland. If you are adopting the child as a couple, and one of you is the child’s mother or father or relative, only one of you must be at least 21. There is no upper age limit for adoptive parents. You can adopt if you are: A married couple living together A couple living together in a civil partnership A couple cohabiting together (living together and in a committed relationship) for at least 3 years The mother, father or relative of the child (relative meaning a grandparent, brother, sister, uncle or aunt of the child, and/or the spouse of any such person; the relationship to the child being traced through the mother or the father) If you are a sole applicant (applying for adoption on your own), and you do not fall into any of the categories listed above, you may only adopt if the Adoption Authority of Ireland is satisfied with the particular circumstances of the case.
results.question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?
results.raw_answer:
You are a warm, empathetic, and knowledgeable assistant for the Irish Citizen's Information service. Respond clearly, simply, and accurately, and use your existing knowledge of official information relevant to Ireland.

Question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:
In Ireland, an individual can adopt a child if they meet certain eligibility criteria, including being over 18 years old, living in Ireland, having no criminal record or previous adoption experience, and demonstrating good character and parenting skills through a background check.
To proceed with adopting, one must also be registered on the Adoption Register. This process is overseen by the Office of the Children’s Guardian (OCG) and involves several steps, such as completing an application form, attending an assessment interview, and possibly undergoing additional assessments.
The OCG provides support throughout this process and ensures that all applicants have access to necessary resources and guidance. They work closely with local authorities, social services, and other agencies to facilitate the best possible outcome for children seeking new homes
results.answer:
In Ireland, an individual can adopt a child if they meet certain eligibility criteria, including being over 18 years old, living in Ireland, having no criminal record or previous adoption experience, and demonstrating good character and parenting skills through a background check.
To proceed with adopting, one must also be registered on the Adoption Register. This process is overseen by the Office of the Children’s Guardian (OCG) and involves several steps, such as completing an application form, attending an assessment interview, and possibly undergoing additional assessments.
The OCG provides support throughout this process and ensures that all applicants have access to necessary resources and guidance.

results.ground_truth: Penalty points are recorded on your driving licence when: You are convicted in court of a driving offence that attracts penalty points or You pay a fixed charge notice that was issued to you for an offence that also carries penalty points If you get 12 penalty points in any 3 year period, you are automatically disqualified from driving for 6 months. Learner permit drivers are disqualified if they have 7 penalty points. This lower threshold also applies for the first 2 years of a driver’s first full driving licence. Penalty points are not added to your licence immediately. Fixed charge and penalty offences Fixed notice penalties are issued for driving offences that attract penalty points and/or just a fine. If you receive a fixed notice penalty, you will be issued a notice by the Department of Transport. If you pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a further notice from the Department of Transport confirming that the penalty points will be added to your driving licence. The penalty points will be added to your licence 28 days after that. If you do not pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a summons to appear in the District Court. If you are convicted of a driving offence in court, the court will notify the Department of Transport of the number of penalty points attached to that conviction. The Department of Transport will then issue a notification that these penalty points will be added to your driving licence 28 days after the notification date. You can get information on fixed charge notices and fines in our document on driving offences.

Question: How do penalty points work?

Helpful Answer:
Penalty points in Ireland can be confusing at first glance. They are used by the Garda Síochána (Irish police) as part of their system for enforcing traffic regulations. When you receive a fine for breaking a law while driving, one point is added to your licence.
The number of points on your licence reflects how many times you have been fined for similar offences over the last 3 years. If you accumulate too many points, it can lead to more severe consequences such as a ban from driving or even jail time.
It’s important to note that if you drive without insurance or with an invalid license, these could also result in points being added to your licence. The Garda Síochána has strict rules about
results.answer:
Penalty points in Ireland can be confusing at first glance. They are used by the Garda Síochána (Irish police) as part of their system for enforcing traffic regulations. When you receive a fine for breaking a law while driving, one point is added to your licence.
The number of points on your licence reflects how many times you have been fined for similar offences over the last 3 years. If you accumulate too many points, it can lead to more severe consequences such as a ban from driving or even jail time.
It’s important to note that if you drive without insurance or with an invalid license, these could also result in points being added to your licence.

results.ground_truth: To be eligible for a statutory redundancy payment, you must: Be over 16 Be in employment that is fully insurable under the Social Welfare Acts Have at least 2 years’ continuous employment (104 weeks) with the same employer over the age of 16 Have been made redundant (dismissed from your job). You must have been dismissed from your job To show you were dismissed, your employment must have been terminated (with or without notice). There will also be a dismissal if you have ended your contract of employment because you were forced to leave your job because of your employer’s conduct. This is known as constructive dismissal.
results.question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?

Question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?

Helpful Answer:
Redundancy is an unfortunate but necessary part of any business strategy, especially in today’s fast-paced world where technology can disrupt industries overnight. If you're concerned about redundancy, it's important to understand what constitutes redundancy in the context of employment law in Ireland.

In Ireland, if an employer needs to reduce their workforce or close down a branch due to economic or operational reasons, they must provide employees with reasonable notice before making redundancies. The length of this notice period varies depending on the type of employee (permanent vs. casual) and the circumstances surrounding the redundancy decision.

For permanent employees who have worked at least two years in total, the minimum notice required is 4 weeks. For those who have worked less than two years, the notice period could
results.answer:
Redundancy is an unfortunate but necessary part of any business strategy, especially in today’s fast-paced world where technology can disrupt industries overnight. If you're concerned about redundancy, it's important to understand what constitutes redundancy in the context of employment law in Ireland.

In Ireland, if an employer needs to reduce their workforce or close down a branch due to economic or operational reasons, they must provide employees with reasonable notice before making redundancies. The length of this notice period varies depending on the type of employee (permanent vs. casual) and the circumstances surrounding the redundancy decision.

For permanent employees who have worked at least two years in total, the minimum notice required is 4 weeks.

results.ground_truth: You must complete the application form and provide supporting documents. You can apply for most payments online. You can also get an application form from your local Intreo Centre or Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre. You can also get an application form on gov.ie. Your Intreo Centre, Social Welfare Branch Office or your local Citizens Information Centre can help you fill in your application form. Birth certs for social welfare You are no longer required to provide copies of birth certificates for social welfare purposes if you were born in Ireland and your birth is in the Register of Births. The Department of Social Protection can access this information directly. You can get more information about getting a Birth, Marriage or Death certificate.

results.ground_truth: Citizens Information Services (CISs) provide face-to-face services to the public. Through trained staff and volunteers, CISs provide free, impartial and confidential information, advice and advocacy services to the public. Each Citizens Information Service covers a geographical area and delivers the service through a network of Citizen Information Centres (CICs). There are eight individual regional Citizens Information Services which are companies limited by guarantee and are registered charities. They cover the following areas: North Dublin, Dublin South, North Connacht and Ulster, North Leinster, North Munster, South Connacht, South Leinster and South Munster facilitating both rural and urban areas. CISs provide information on various topics, including; Employment rights Income support Social welfare Family matters Health services Housing Education Immigration
results.question: What is the Citizens Information Service?

Question: What is the Citizens Information Service?

Helpful Answer:
The Citizens Information Service in Ireland provides free advice on local services such as housing, education, employment, health, and transport. It aims to help people understand their rights and obligations when dealing with government departments, authorities, or bodies. The service offers support through phone calls, emails, face-to-face consultations, and online resources. It covers all 32 counties within the state and operates throughout the year. The service was established in 1987 and has since grown into one of the largest citizen information services in Europe. Its aim is to make it easier for citizens to access information about their entitlements and responsibilities, and to ensure that they can fully participate in the public life of the country. Is there anything else you'd like me to

results.ground_truth: People aged between 18 and 24 and: Had been out of work and getting a qualifying payment (see below) for at least 12 months or Faced a significant barrier to work (if unemployed for less than 12 months) What were the qualifying payments? You must have been getting one of the following payments for at least 12 months: Jobseeker's Benefit, Jobseeker's Allowance, Jobseeker's Transitional payment, One-Parent Family Payment, Disability Allowance, Blind Person’s Pension, or Supplementary Welfare Allowance. Other schemes that counted towards the qualifying period The 12-month qualifying period could also have included time spent on schemes such as: SOLAS training apprenticeships, Youthreach, Back to Education Allowance, Fastrack to Information Technology and Tús.

Question: Who was eligible for YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme)?

Helpful Answer:
The Youth Employment Support Scheme (YESS) in Ireland is designed to support young people aged 16-24 who are unemployed or underemployed, and who have not been employed continuously since leaving school or training. The scheme provides financial assistance, including income supplements and access to employment services such as job search advice, work experience placements, and career development opportunities.
To be eligible for YESS, an applicant must meet certain criteria, which can include:

- Being aged between 16 and 24
- Having been out of full-time education or training for at least six months
- Being unemployed or underemployed, meaning that they are unable to find suitable employment within their field of study or interest
- Not having received any other form
results.answer: The Youth Employment Support Scheme (YESS) in Ireland is designed to support young people aged 16-24 who are unemployed or underemployed, and who have not been employed continuously since leaving school or training. The scheme provides financial assistance, including income supplements and access to employment services such as job search advice, work experience placements, and career development opportunities.

results.ground_truth: If you are a carer you may need to take breaks. Respite care is when you can take a break from caring, and the person you care for is looked after by someone else. It can be covered by family members or an organisation so you can take a short break, a holiday or a rest. Respite care can be for carers of older people or people with different disabilities. Respite care can cover different lengths of time such as: A very short time, for example for an evening Or a much longer arrangement, for example for a holiday Respite care schemes are sometimes called 'Breakaway' or 'Friendship' schemes.

Question: What is respite care?

Helpful Answer:
Respite care refers to short-term care provided by paid or unpaid caregivers who visit clients in their homes. This can be particularly beneficial for those with chronic conditions or disabilities, as it allows them to take a break from caregiving responsibilities while still receiving support. Respite services may include personal care, medication assistance, meal preparation, transportation, and social activities. They also help families manage stress and improve overall quality of life for individuals requiring care at home. If you need more specific information about respite care options available in Ireland, please let me know!

Question: What is a medical card?

Helpful Answer:
A medical card (also known as a health passport or social health insurance card) is a document that provides access to healthcare services in Ireland. It serves as proof of eligibility for public healthcare benefits, including free healthcare and subsidised prescription medication. The card can be used at any pharmacy or healthcare provider where you have an appointment with them, allowing you to receive free medicines and cover hospital visits without having to pay out-of-pocket. To apply for a medical card, individuals typically need to meet certain income criteria set by the state, which varies depending on their specific circumstances. Once approved, they will receive their card from the Department of Health, who then distribute it through local pharmacies or directly to the individual upon request. This ensures that everyone has equal access to

It serves as proof of eligibility for public healthcare benefits, including free healthcare and subsidised prescription medication. The card can be used at any pharmacy or healthcare provider where you have an appointment with them, allowing you to receive free medicines and cover hospital visits without having to pay out-of-pocket. To apply for a medical card, individuals typically need to meet certain income criteria set by the state, which varies depending on their specific circumstances. Once approved, they will receive their card from the Department of Health, who then distribute it through local pharmacies or directly to the individual upon request.

results.ground_truth: Pre-nuptial agreements have no basis in law in Ireland. As a result, they are not strictly binding. This means that if you have a pre-nuptial agreement in place and you end up in court following the breakdown of your marriage, the judge is not bound by the terms of the pre-nuptial agreement. The only provision in Irish law is under sections 113 and 113A of the Succession Act 1965 (as amended) where a spouse or a civil partner can renounce his/her legal right share in a pre-nuptial agreement. Although they are not legally binding, there is nothing in Irish law which stops a couple planning to marry from having and signing a pre-nuptial agreement. Importantly, such agreements can serve as guides for the courts in judicial separation and divorce cases. If a pre-nuptial agreement makes ‘proper provision’ for each person it is more likely to be persuasive on the judge. Therefore, in situations where one party is likely to inherit a significant family farm or business, it will guide the judge in the divorce or judicial separation on what the parties’ intentions were at the outset.
results.question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?
results.raw_answer:

Question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?

Helpful Answer:
Pre-nuptial agreements are legally binding contracts between two people who have decided to get married or enter into a civil partnership. They can be used as an alternative way to divide property if one person marries someone they already had a relationship with before marriage.
It is important to note that while these agreements may provide some protection in terms of asset division during divorce proceedings, they do not always prevent the court from making any orders it deems necessary. It is recommended to seek advice from a solicitor experienced in this area to understand how such agreements might affect you specifically. 

This answer provides accurate and clear information about the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements in Ireland, addressing key points including their purpose, legality, and potential limitations. The response also
results.answer:
Pre-nuptial agreements are legally binding contracts between two people who have decided to get married or enter into a civil partnership. They can be used as an alternative way to divide property if one person marries someone they already had a relationship with before marriage.
It is important to note that while these agreements may provide some protection in terms of asset division during divorce proceedings, they do not always prevent the court from making any orders it deems necessary. It is recommended to seek advice from a solicitor experienced in this area to understand how such agreements might affect you specifically.

results.ground_truth: The Department of Transport regulates air transport. This includes commercial and private services. EU airlines can fly freely within the EU/European Economic Area (EEA). They can do this without any restrictions on flight frequency or routes. Airlines from countries outside of the EU/EEA must request permission. They must do this each time they want to fly to, from, or over Ireland. The Department of Defence regulates military air transport in Ireland.
results.question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?
results.raw_answer:

Question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:
The regulation of aviation in Ireland is primarily overseen by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA). The CAA is responsible for ensuring that all aspects of air travel are safe, efficient, and fair for passengers, pilots, and airlines. They also regulate airspace, aircraft operations, and airport facilities. While there may be some oversight from other bodies depending on specific regulations or incidents, the primary regulatory body is the CAA. If you have any questions about aviation safety or regulations, I'd be happy to help with general information or answer specific queries related to airline services, flight schedules, or airport procedures. Let me know if you need assistance with anything else! 🚀

results.ground_truth: Under the Cycle to Work Scheme (also known as the Bike to Work Scheme), you can get a new bike tax free through your work. Your employer pays for a new bike and then you repay the cost of regular instalments from your gross (overall) salary. You do not have to pay tax, PRSI or the Universal Social Charge on your repayments. Not every employer takes part in the scheme. However, if they do, they must offer it to all their employees. If you are self-employed, you cannot take part in the Cycle to Work Scheme unless you pay PRSI as an employee in addition to your self-employed work.

Question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?

Helpful Answer:
The Cycle to Work Scheme (CTWS) was introduced in 2013 as part of an initiative by the Government of Ireland to encourage cycling and reduce air pollution. The scheme allows individuals to purchase a new bicycle or cycle-related equipment such as helmets and lights at a reduced cost, with no need to pay VAT on these items.
Under the CTWS, eligible employees can claim up to £500 towards the purchase of a qualifying bike from participating employers. To be eligible, you must have worked for the same employer for at least one year and meet certain criteria, including being aged between 18-64 years old and not having used public transport within the last three months. You will also need to provide proof of income and
results.answer:
The Cycle to Work Scheme (CTWS) was introduced in 2013 as part of an initiative by the Government of Ireland to encourage cycling and reduce air pollution. The scheme allows individuals to purchase a new bicycle or cycle-related equipment such as helmets and lights at a reduced cost, with no need to pay VAT on these items.
Under the CTWS, eligible employees can claim up to £500 towards the purchase of a qualifying bike from participating employers. To be eligible, you must have worked for the same employer for at least one year and meet certain criteria, including being aged between 18-64 years old and not having used public transport within the last three months.

Question: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?

Helpful Answer:
The Luas operates on a flexible schedule based on passenger demand, but generally has peak hours during rush hour when there is high volume of passengers. The Luas also has off-peak hours which operate at different frequencies depending on the route. For more detailed information, please visit the Luas website or contact customer service directly.
